'''Larry Hamilton''' (March 23, 1951 – December 28, 2011)<ref name="Obits"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[New Orleans blues]], [[rhythm and blues]] and [[soul blues]] singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> Although he had been a professional musician since the mid-1960s, his solo debut album was not released until 1997.

==Biography==
'''Larry James Hamilton''',<ref name="Obits"/> was born in [[Galveston]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] but was brought up in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]]. Playing drums, piano and learning to sing by the age of nine, Hamilton had written his first song by the age of 12.  Three years later, in 1965, Hamilton began his professional career as lead singer with David Batiste and the Gladiators. His career there lasted until the mid-1970s, during which time he had toured with [[Curtis Mayfield]], [[Bettye Swann]], [[Jackie Wilson]], [[Percy Sledge]], [[David Ruffin]], [[Major Lance]], [[Z. Z. Hill]] and [[Al Green]].<ref name="AMG"/> In his own name, Hamilton recorded two singles on [[Malaco Records]], "Gossip" b/w "Keep The News To Yourself" (1971), and "My Mind Keeps Playing Tricks On Me" b/w "Ain't Nothing Like That Funky Music".<ref name="Home">{{cite web |url=http://homeofthegroove.blogspot.com/2008/04/larry-hamilton-on-record-and-in.html |title=Larry Hamilton: On Record|author= |date= |work= |publisher=Homeofthegroove.blogspot.com |accessdate=September 18, 2011}}</ref>

His songwriting credits include [[Etta James]]' "Get On Your Job"; "Feel Like Dynamite" and "Let Us Be" for [[King Floyd]]; "She's Taking My Part" for [[Irma Thomas]]; and "The Feeling" for [[Albert King]]. He has also written for [[Oliver Morgan]] ("I Love Rhythm and Blues"); [[Jean Knight]] (Save The Last Kiss For Me"); and [[Johnny Adams]] ("More Than One Way").<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Home"/>

Hamilton met [[Allen Toussaint]] in the late 1970s and accompanied his group on tour. In 1996, Toussaint signed Hamilton to his NYNO Records label, releasing ''Larry Hamilton'' in 1997.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=guitar-slim-jr-p203261/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Larry Hamilton |author=Richard Skelly |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 18, 2011}}</ref> Hamilton's second album, ''Love Is?'', was released in September 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nothing-nice-r1096227/credits |title=''Love Is ?'' |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=September 18, 2011}}</ref>

Hamilton died in December 2011, aged 60.<ref name="Obits"/>
